page.title: 02STANWICK CAMP & EARTHWORKS
page.content: Much of the {ancient earthworks forming the {defence system} of the {Brigante tribe}who lived in this area between the{Roman invasions}of{55 B.C. and {43 A.D.} remain clearly visible. They are extensive and the resulting enclosure is thought to have been capable of holding the entire tribe estimated at between {80 & 100,000} in number. The length of the outward ramparts is 8,070yards, of the outward works 3,183 and of the internal works 2,334. Today parts stand up to 20feet in height and with the erosion caused through nearly 2,000years of exposure to the weather, must originally have been much higher. { Excavation}work {c.1848} revealed a large number of horse trappings; metal bowls;bronze axes and spear heads;some embossed bronzes, one of which,a{water {clock,}is now in the{British Museum.}
